questions.solution:

questions.text: A patient complaining of pain in the right flank has been diagnosed with right-sided renal calculi measuring 2.2cm. Urine microscopy findings are shown in the image below. What is the most suitable treatment for this patient?

choices.text: No treatment required just pain management suffices

questions.solution:
The image of the urine microscopy shows hexagonal-shaped cystine stones. Hence the best suitable treatment for this patient with cystine renal calculi measuring 2.2 cm is percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL).

Cystine stone is relatively resistant to extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy and a stone size of more than 2 cm necessitates percutaneous nephrolithotomy. Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy is done until the renal stone size of less than 1.5cm.

PCNL is indicated in the following condition:

  • If the patient has anatomical obstruction like pelviureteric junction obstruction, calyceal diverticula, or distal ureteral obstruction.
  • Hard renal stones like cystine stones, and calcium oxalate stones.
  • If the renal stone is struvite stone as it is associated with urinary tract infection.

Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) is a non-invasive method that generates shockwaves outside the body, which are focused on the stones. It is the commonest method of treating urinary tract stones nowadays. Stones up to approximately 1.5 cm in size are suitable for this form of treatment.

Complications of ESWL include infection, haematuria, parenchymal hemorrhage, and perirenal hematoma. ESWL is contraindicated in obese patients, pregnant patients, and patients taking oral anticoagulants.

Note: Stone fragments collected in the distal ureter following ESWL are called steinstrasse.

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

choices.text: Safer in procedures closer to vital structures

questions.solution:
The given instrument is Monopolar electrocautery. Both cutting and coagulation modes are possible with monopolar electrocautery.

A short circuit is established in bipolar electrocautery between the tips of the instrument. This makes the chances of burns lesser compared to monopolar electrocautery. Bipolar electrocautery has less lateral dissipation of current so it is safer in procedures closure to vital structures.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male who is a known case of peripheral arterial disease comes with complaints of pain over the calf and a leg ulcer. His ankle-brachial pressure index was measured and the value was 2. What does it signify?
questions.solution:
The ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI) value of 2 is suggestive of calcified vessels.

The Ankle-Brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the ipsilateral arm. The highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery is taken as the numerator, with the highest pressure in the brachial artery being the denominator. It can be used as an initial, bedside test for peripheral arterial disease. 

Interpretation:

  • >0.9 to < 1.4 – Normal
  • <0.9 – Hemodynamically significant arterial lesion.
  • <0.4 –Chronic limb-threatening ischemia(may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene)
  • > 1.4 - Calcified vessels

Medial sclerosis and calcification of the arterial wall cause artificially high ABPI readings of  >1.4. It is typically seen in patients with diabetes mellitus (DM).

Digital arteries in the toe are rarely affected by sclerosis. Hence, toe–brachial pressure index (TBI) in combination with ABPI is a more reliable tool for the detection of significant large-vessel steno-occlusive disease in patients with DM. A TBI value of less than 0.6 suggests a significant arterial lesion.

Related Pearl: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle-brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery and the denominator is the highest brachial systolic pressure.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.9 to <1.4 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.4 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.
>1.4 Signifies poor compressibility of the arteries. Mostly due to calcification because of increased age, diabetes etc.

Note: A fall in the resting ABPI of more than 20% after exercise is indicative of arterial disease.

questions.text: A surgery resident during the rounds advised the intern to monitor the burns patient for adequate fluid resuscitation and also instructed him to give a bolus of 10 mL/kg body weight if the patient showed signs of hypoperfusion. All of the following are indications to give bolus fluid, except:
questions.solution:
A low hematocrit does not indicate a need for fluid resuscitation.

Instead, a high hematocrit is an indicator of hypoperfusion. 

Urine output is the best measure to monitor for the adequacy of fluid resuscitation. Urine output should be between 0.5 and 1.0 mL/kg body weight per hour. If the urine output is below this, the infusion rate should be increased by 50%. If the urine output is inadequate and the patient is showing signs of hypoperfusion, then a bolus of 10 mL/kg body weight should be given.

Signs of hypoperfusion include:

  • Restlessness with tachycardia,
  • Cool peripheries 
  • High hematocrit

questions.text: A patient is posted for esophagectomy for the presence of esophageal carcinoma in the middle third of the esophagus. During the operation, the surgeon performs laparotomy and constructs a gastric tube. After this, he performs a right thoracotomy and removes the tumor. He then anastomoses the remaining part of the esophagus with the stomach in the upper part of the thorax. What is the type of esophagectomy done by the surgeon?
questions.solution:
The resection of a tumor in the middle third of the esophagus by laparotomy and right thoracotomy is called the Ivor Lewis approach. 

In the Ivor Lewis approach, partial esophagectomy and esophagogastric anastomosis are done in the thorax. 

Other approaches in esophagectomy:

  • Orringer approach (option B) is used for tumors in the lower part of the esophagus. The stomach is mobilized through a midline abdominal incision or by laparotomy, and the tumor is removed. The cervical esophagus is mobilized through an incision in the neck, and anastomosis of the remaining part of the esophagus and the stomach is performed. This is a palliative procedure. 
  • McKeown approach (option C) is used for the tumors in the upper part of the esophagus. In this technique, the surgeon performs laparotomy and thoracotomy to remove the tumor. A right-side neck approach is done for the anastomosis between the pharynx and stomach. 

McEvedy approach (option A) is used in the repair of the femoral hernia. The surgeon reaches the site of the hernia via a horizontal incision in the lower part of the abdomen, centered at the lateral edge of the rectus muscle.

Related Pearl: Replacement conduits after esophagectomy

  • Best conduit of choice after carcinoma esophagus resection – Stomach
  • Best conduit of choice after benign disorders – Colon
  • Best conduit of choice after short segment replacement – Jejunum
  • Gastric conduit is based on right gastric and gastroepiploic arteries
  • Left colon conduit is based on left colic artery
  • The posterior mediastinal route is preferred for placement of conduit as it is the shortest route.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about mesenteric cysts?

choices.text: There is a zone of resonance around the cyst
Most common presentation is of a painless abdominal swelling

questions.solution:
Positive Tillaux’s sign is seen in a mesenteric cyst. Tillaux's sign is said to be positive if the mass/swelling is mobile, perpendicular to the mesentery attachment line.

Mesenteric cysts occur either in the small intestine (60%) or the colon (40%) and can be classified as the following:

  • Chylolymphatic (most common type)
  • Enterogenous
  • Urogenital remnant
  • Dermoid

They occur most commonly in adults. More common in females. The most common presentation is that of a painless abdominal swelling with the characteristic physical signs:

  • Fluctuant swelling near the umbilicus
  • Swelling moves freely in a plane at right angles to the attachment of the mesentery (Tillaux’s sign) 
  • Presence of zone of resonance around the cyst

Other presentations include

  • Recurrent attacks of abdominal pain - due to temporary impaction of a food bolus in a segment of bowel narrowed by the cyst
  • Vomiting
  • Acute abdominal complications, such as:
    • Torsion of the cyst
    • Rupture of the cyst
    • Haemorrhage into the cyst
    • Infection

Ultrasonography and CT scans are used to demonstrate mesenteric cysts.

The treatment of mesenteric cysts is complete excision by enucleation, although bowel resection is frequently required to ensure that the remaining bowel is viable.

If enucleation or resection is not possible, partial excision with marsupialization of the remaining cyst into the abdominal cavity is done.

questions.text: A person posted for nephrolithotomy was placed in a surgical position as shown in the image below. Traction injury of which of the following structures is a potential complication of this position?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the lateral or kidney position used in urological and retroperitoneal procedures. Traction injury of the brachial plexus is a potential complication of this position.

The modified lateral position called the kidney position is used in urological and retroperitoneal procedures. Here, the lower leg of the patient is slightly flexed at the knee. A pillow is placed between both legs and the upper leg is flexed in a more exaggerated position. Arms are fixed in the stirrups.

Complications associated with this procedure are:

  • Respiratory complications due to more ventilation of one lung over the other.
  • Traction injury of the brachial plexus and ulnar nerve.
  • Corneal abrasions and ocular trauma.
 

Entrapment of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is seen with lithotomy position, prone position and beach chair position.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presented with burns injury. His face and neck are covered with burns along with both the arms and sides of the chest. He requires both crystalloids and colloid resuscitation. Which of the following will you not follow while resuscitating the patient in the first 24 hours?

choices.text: Human albumin solution (HAS) is  commonly used
Muir and Barclay formula is used for calculation of colloids
Urine output should be between 0.5 to 1 ml/kg body wt/hour
Proteins should be given within the first 12 hours of burn

questions.solution:
Proteins should be given after the first 12 hours of burn because proteins leak out of the cells due to intravascular fluid shifts in the first 12 hours of burn. 

Human albumin solution (HAS) is commonly used for colloid resuscitation.

The most common colloid-based formula is the Muir and Barclay formula. It is calculated as -0.5 × percentage body surface area burnt × weight = one portion.

Urine output is a commonly used parameter to monitor resuscitation and it should be between 0.5 to 1 ml/kg body weight per hour.

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

<14 years 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1

Dextrose maintenance:

  • 100 ml/ kg in 24 hours for 10 kg
  • 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg
  • 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

  • Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

  • 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl child is brought with a history of abdominal pain and diarrhea. Examination reveals darkening around both eyes, proptosis, and rapid jerky eye movements. There is a palpable abdominal mass with abdominal distention. Laboratory examination shows hypokalemia. The mass is excised and histopathological examination shows a small round blue cell tumor with Homer-Wright pseudorosettes. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of neuroblastoma. The child presents with abdominal pain and a mass. Biopsy of the mass shows characteristic Homer-Wright pseudorosettes which point towards the diagnosis. The diarrhoea, hypokalemia and ocular features in this patient are a result of the paraneoplastic syndromes associated with this condition. This tumor arises from the adrenal glands and urinary catecholamines may be used to diagnose and monitor this tumour.

Neuroblastomas arise from the neural crest cells and are the most common intra-abdominal and extracranial solid tumours in children. Most patients present before the age of 5 years. There has been an association established with fetal alcohol syndrome, neurofibromatosis, fetal hydantoin syndrome and Hirschsprung's disease.

Genetics - Rearrangement or deletion of the short arm of chromosome 1 is seen in many patients. The N-MYC gene is used as a biomarker for risk stratification. Expression of this oncogene, which is seen in about 20% of the patients, is associated with aggressive disease. Hyperdiploidy is associated with a favourable prognosis in children. Loss of heterozygosity in 1p, 11q, 14q, and gain of 17q are associated with a worse prognosis.

Clinical features:

Approximately two-thirds of the cases arise in the abdomen and most of these cases arise from the adrenal glands. Other sites include the organs of ZuckerKandl, posterior mediastinum, pelvis, head, and neck. 

The symptoms associated with this condition are -

  • abdominal mass (retroperitoneal or hepatic)
  • Pain - abdominal pain or localized back pain or bone pain
  • constipation
  • proptosis
  • periorbital ecchymoses ("raccoon eyes," from periorbital ecchymosis caused by orbital metastases)
  • Horner syndrome (miosis, ptosis, anhidrosis)
  • weakness (from spinal cord compression)
  • scoliosis
  • bladder dysfunction
  • palpable non-tender subcutaneous blue subcutaneous nodules represent skin dissemination of tumour associated with the "Blueberry Muffin Syndrome".
  • opsoclonus myoclonus syndrome
  • secretory diarrhea (from paraneoplastic production of vasoactive intestinal polypeptide [VIP])
  • systemic symptoms (fever, weight loss)
  • anemia
  • heterochromia iridis (different colors of the iris or portions of the iris)
  • hypertension - due to secretion of catecholamines
  • unilateral nasal obstruction

Paraneoplastic syndrome:

  • Opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome - It occurs in about 1-3% of patients with neuroblastoma. The characteristics symptoms are rapid, dancing eye movements, rhythmic jerking (myoclonus) involving limbs or trunk, and/or ataxia.
  • Secretion of VIP - It causes abdominal distention and intractable secretory diarrhea with hypokalemia. Serum VIP levels will be >75 pg/ml

Classification: Shimada classification is used for classifying neuroblastoma.

Diagnosis:

  • Histopathology is the gold standard for diagnosis. A biopsy will show the presence of small round blue cell tumor with Homer-Wright pseudorosettes.
  • Other investigations that would aid in the diagnosis include CBC, urinary catecholamine excretion, bone marrow aspiration and biopsy, nuclear imaging with an I-131 MIBG scan, and CT to detect metastasis.

The mainstay of treatment is resection of the tumor, chemotherapy, and radiation. The tumors which have spread to other places will require surgery, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy. Important chemotherapeutic agents used are vincristine, cyclophosphamide, topotecan, doxorubicin, cisplatin, and etoposide. 

An image of histopathology of neuroblastoma is shown below.

 

Nephroblastoma:

Wilm's tumor is the most common renal neoplasm of childhood. Clinically, the most common finding is an asymptomatic abdominal mass. Hematuria, hypertension, fever, weight loss, tumor rupture causing acute abdomen are other presentations of the disease. The most common site of metastasis of Wilms tumor is the lungs. On microscopy, the classic triphasic combination of blastemal (small, round blue cells), stromal, and epithelial cell types is observed in most lesions, although the percentage of each component is variable. Nephrogenic rests are precursor lesions of Wilms tumors. 

Rhabdoid tumour of the kidney:

Rhabdoid tumor of the kidney is the most aggressive and lethal childhood renal tumor and accounts for 2% of renal tumors.

Rhabdomyosarcoma:

Rhabdomyosarcomas are the most common soft tissue tumor. The older age of the child presenting with proptosis suggests Rhabdomyosarcoma (average age 7 to 8 years) generally. But, the histopathology would show elongated to round spindle cells with features of skeletal muscle different stages of embryogenesis with highly eosinophilic cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei – the embryonal type of RMS

Rhabdomyosarcoma is classified into 4 major subtypes

    1. Embryonal: Makes up 80% of orbital rhabdomyosarcomas and presents most commonly in young children (mean age 7-8)
    2. Alveolar subtype exhibits small, round, densely appearing cells that are loosely arranged, with septae that are similar to the alveoli of the lung; carries the worst prognosis
    3. Botryoid - variant of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma; subepithelial grape-like aggregates of tumor cells; seen most commonly in infants.
    4. Pleomorphic

Immunohistochemistry is useful in identifying skeletal muscle proteins, such as alpha-actin, myosin, desmin and myoglobin

Rhabdomyosarcoma shows a strong tendency for local invasion, local recurrence, and hematogenous and lymphatic metastase

 

Note:

Neuroblastoma is the most common abdominal (extracranial) solid tumor of childhood.

Wilms tumor, or nephroblastoma, is the most common primary malignant renal tumor of childhood. The renal origin of the mass is usually apparent on computed tomography (CT), but it can be mistaken for neuroblastoma. Wilm's tumor shows peripheral calcification in contrast-enhanced CT, unlike intratumoral calcifications and vascular encasement, which are observed in neuroblastoma.

questions.text: Prophylactic thyroidectomy is indicated in patients with which of the following features:

choices.text: Marfanoid habitus, multiple neuromas on the lip and familial pheochromocytoma,
Dense lymphatic infiltration of the thyroid detected on FNAC

questions.solution:
Prophylactic thyroidectomy is indicated in MEN 2B syndrome as they can develop medullary thyroid carcinoma. This syndrome manifests as:

  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Marfanoid habitus
  • Mucosal neuromas
  • Medullary thyroid cancer. 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) can be inherited as familial MTC, MEN 2A or MEN 2B syndromes. These conditions are autosomal dominant and occur due to RET proto-oncogene mutation. As almost all cases of MEN 2B develop medullary thyroid cancer, a prophylactic thyroidectomy may be performed even during infancy.

Option A: The most common malignancy in thyroglossal cysts is papillary thyroid carcinoma. In such a case, Sistrunk operation with total thyroidectomy is considered.

Option C: Hashimoto's thyroiditis shows dense lymphatic infiltration of the thyroid detected on FNAC which is treated with thyroxine. However, total thyroidectomy is performed in malignant transformation to thyroid lymphoma.

Option D: Upregulation of BRAF is associated with papillary thyroid carcinoma.

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text: What is the most common benign tumor of the lung?
questions.solution:
The most common benign tumor of the lung is hamartoma.

Hamartoma is a developmental abnormality containing mesothelial and endothelial elements. They are manifested by the overgrowth of cartilage. It is typically seen in 40-60 years of age, more common in males.

It is usually seen in the periphery of the lung and grows slowly. Popcorn calcification in chest X-ray is suggestive of a hamartoma.

Chest X-ray showing a popcorn calcification in the apex of the right lung.

 

Diagnosis and definitive treatment are achieved by excision of the lesion.

Gross specimen showing hamartoma of the lung.

Note: Popcorn calcification is also seen in:

  • Chondroid lesions like chondrosarcoma
  • Fibrous dysplasia
  • Fibroadenoma breast
  • Calcified uterine fibroid
  • Metaphyses and epiphyses of long bones of children with osteogenesis imperfecta

questions.text: A man with a history of TB infection 2 years ago comes with complaints of lower urinary tract infection. Urinalysis revealed pus cells but urine culture is negative. What is the earliest finding seen on cystoscopy in his condition?

choices.text: Ulcerative lesions over the trigone and the ureteric orifices
Linear mucosal ulcerations over the fundus of the bladder
Mucosal pallor around the ureteric orifices

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of tuberculous cystitis. The earliest sign of tuberculosis of the bladder observed by cystoscopy is pallor of the mucosa around the ureteric orifice due to submucosal edema. 

Subsequently, tubercles may be seen and, in longstanding cases, there is marked fibrosis and the capacity of the bladder is greatly reduced. This is known as a thimble bladder.

The IV urogram below shows a thimble bladder which is seen in tuberculous cystitis. 

Tuberculous urinary infection is secondary to renal tuberculosis. Early tuberculosis of the bladder starts around the ureteric orifice or trigone. Urinalysis reveals pus cells without organisms and urine culture is negative. 

The patient is usually started on anti-tubercular drugs and they rapidly respond to treatment. If bladder volume is greatly reduced, bladder augmentation surgery is done to avoid the risk of upper tract damage due to high filling pressure and vesicoureteric reflux. Bladder augmentation is done by ileocystoplasty or caecocystoplasty. 

Option A: Ulcerative lesions over trigone and ureteric orifices are seen in later stages as tuberculous cystitis progress to thimble bladder. 

Option B: Linear mucosal ulcerations over the fundus of the bladder characteristic of Hunner's patch or Hunner's ulcer are observed in interstitial cystitis.

Option C: Erythema over the bladder wall seen on cystoscopy warrants a biopsy to rule out bladder carcinoma-in-situ.

questions.text: In a 30-year-old male who underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the bile duct was injured. The area of injury is shown in the image below. Which type of bile duct injury does this belong to, according to Strasberg’s classification of bile duct injuries?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a bile leak from the main bile duct without any major tissue loss. According to Strasberg’s classification, the image given belongs to type D bile duct injury.

Biliary injury may occur post-laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The most common site of bile leak following cholecystectomy is the cystic duct.

MRCP is the gold standard for evaluating the biliary tree's morphology completely. MRCP with magnetic resonance angiography is more useful in cases of associated vascular injury. An HIDA scan can confirm the presence of a bile leak or biliary obstruction. The Strasberg classification of bile duct injury is a widely used system to anatomically define these injuries by location:

  • Type A: Bile leak from cystic duct stump or a minor biliary radical in the gallbladder fossa
  • Type B: Occluded right posterior sectoral duct
  • Type C: Bile leak from the divided right posterior sectoral duct
  • Type D: Bile leak from the main bile duct without major tissue loss
  • Type E: Injury to the main hepatic duct; classified according to the level of injury
    • E1: Transected main bile duct with a stricture more than 2cm from the hilus
    • E2: Transected main bile duct with a stricture less than 2cm from the hilus
    • E3: Stricture of the hilus with right and left ducts in communication
    • E4: Stricture of the hilus with separation of right and left hepatic ducts
    • E5: Stricture of the right aberrant sectoral duct and the main bile duct

For an unstable patient, temporary external biliary drainage is achieved by passing a catheter percutaneously into an intrahepatic duct. When the condition improves, definitive surgery can be undertaken. The main principle of surgery is to maintain the duct length and the restoration of biliary drainage.

questions.solution:
Applying gentle pressure over the lateral lobes of the thyroid producing stridor is known as Kocher’s Test

Kocher’s Test: Done when one suspects pressure on the trachea. Gentle pressure on the lateral lobes of the thyroid causes stridor due to a narrow trachea. This test is positive in Multinodular Goitre and carcinoma infiltrating into the trachea. 

The Kocher eponyms:-

  1. Kocher’s thyroid dissector - used during a thyroidectomy to dissect the upper pole of the thyroid.
  2. Kocher’s transverse collar incision is centrally placed 4-6 cm transverse incision 1 cm below the cricoid cartilage parallel to the normal skin lines of the neck.
  3. Kocher incision - a subcostal incision used to gain access for gall bladder and/or biliary tree pathology. Commonly used in open cholecystectomy.
  4. The Kocher Criteria for Septic Arthritis distinguishes septic arthritis from transient synovitis in a child with an inflamed hip.
  5. The posterior approach used in the operative management of acetabular fractures is known as the Kocher-Langenbeck approach.
  6. Kocher’s technique for reduction of shoulder dislocation - TEAM (Traction → External Rotation → Adduction → Medial Rotation)
  7. Kocher’s hemostatic forceps has opposing tooth in the tip and serrations in the distal blades. Used to hold pedicles, tough structures, cut ends of muscles, Hold ribs during rib dissection, hold gauze for blunt dissection, hold resected bowel.


Note: Not all Kocher refers to the same person

Other options:

Pemberton's sign: The patient is asked to raise the hands above the head such that the arms touch the ears. This results in the engorgement of neck veins. It is seen in obstruction to major veins of the thorax.

Lahey's Method: Examiner stands in front of the patient and the lobes are pushed to one side for palpation. For palpating the left lobe, the examiner should push the right lobe medially by the left hand and the left lobe is palpated with the right hand of the examiner. 

Callaway Test: The vertical circumference of the axilla is increased on the dislocated side as compared to the normal side, in case of shoulder dislocation.

A per rectal examination of a patient revealed an enlarged nodular prostate with adherent rectal mucosa. PSA was found to be 25 ng/ml. A biopsy was done which showed adenocarcinoma of the prostate. Which of the following zones of the prostate is likely to be involved in this pathology?

PSA: Prostate specific antigen
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and findings are suggestive of a case of prostatic carcinoma. Prostatic carcinoma arises from the peripheral zone (marked 2) of the gland.

The prostate has three distinct zones as follows:

ZONE STRUCTURES ENCLOSED CLINICAL SIGNIFICANCE
Transitional zone Urethra  The common site for BPH (benign prostatic hyperplasia)
Central zone Ejaculatory ducts Rarely diseased
Peripheral zone

Central transitional zone

Pre-prostatic urethra

 The common site for prostatic carcinoma

Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) arises from the transitional zone.

Carcinoma of the prostate is the most common malignant tumor in men over the age of 65 years  They may range from indolent lesions that cause no harm to aggressive metastatic tumors. Most cancers are clinically silent and are detected on routine rectal examination or PSA measurements.

Grossly, malignant tissue is gritty and firm in consistency (in contrast to the spongy appearance of benign tissue) and thus more readily palpable on digital rectal examination. 

Only advanced disease gives rise to symptoms:

  • Bladder outlet obstruction
  • Pelvic pain and haematuria
  • Bone pain, arthritis
  • Anemia or pancytopenia
  • Renal failure

PSA (prostate specific antigen) is a glycoprotein peptidase that facilitates the liquefaction of semen. It is useful for screening and for monitoring response to therapy but is neither specific nor sensitive to the condition as it can be elevated due to old age and benign conditions such as prostatitis and BPH. A PSA >10ng/ mL is suggestive of cancer and >35 ng/ml is almost diagnostic of advanced prostate cancer. Following radical prostatectomy, the serum PSA should fall to undetectable levels

A prostate biopsy using an automated gun is used to confirm the diagnosis. Around 12 systematic biopsy cores are obtained. This procedure can be done by transrectal or transperineal approach.

Gleason grading may be used after the biopsy to evaluate the stage of the histopathological specimen. Gleason scores range from 6 to 10 where 6 is a low risk for prostate cancer while 10 is a high risk.

Staging of prostate carcinoma
Tx Primary tumor cannot be assessed
T0 No evidence of primary tumor
T1 Clinically inapparent tumor. Neither palpable nor visible on imaging
T1a Incidental histologic findings in 5% or less of tissue resected
T1b Incidental histologic findings in more than 5% of tissue resected
T1c Tumors identified by needle biopsy (for example, because of elevated PSA)
T2

Tumor confined within the prostate
T2a

A tumor involves one-half of one lobe or less
T2b

Tumor involves more than one-half of one lobe but not both lobes
T2c

Tumor involves both lobes
T3

Tumors extend through the prostate capsule
T3a The extracapsular extension (unilateral or bilateral)
T3b

Tumor invades seminal vesicle(s)
T4 Tumor is fixed or invades adjacent structures other than seminal vesicles, such as the external sphincter, rectum, bladder, levator muscles, and/or pelvic wall

Management of prostatic carcinoma:

Management of prostatic carcinoma   
Stage of cancer Age>70 or Gleason score=6  Age<70 or Gleason score>6    
Early prostate cancer: T1, T2A Active surveillance Radical prostatectomy   
Locally advanced prostate cancer: T2B, T2C, T3, T4, N1 Brachytherapy + Androgen deprivation therapy Brachytherapy + Radical prostatectomy
Metastatic prostate cancer   

Androgen deprivation therapy

Chemotherapy and radiotherapy (hormone-resistant  tumor)

Radiopharmaceutical therapy (hormone-resistant bony metastasis) 

Active surveillance is done when there is:

  • Gleason's score of 6
  • Early-stage disease (T1c)
  • Small volume disease on biopsy
  • Low PSA (< 10 ng/ml)

Active surveillance protocols include a digital rectal examination and PSA monitoring every 3 to 6 months, with TRUS-guided prostate biopsies every 1 to 3 years.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man complained of unsteadiness while walking. The examination is suggestive of cerebellar disease. An MRI revealed cerebellar hemangioblastomas. On further evaluation, the patient was found to have multiple retinal hemangiomas and bilateral renal masses. Based on the histopathological image of the tumor below, what is the likely subtype of renal cell carcinoma in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical features mentioned are consistent with a diagnosis of Von Hippel Lindau's (VHL) disease. The image shows the presence of cells with clear cytoplasm, hence, the most likely subtype of RCC he is suffering from is the clear cell type of RCC.

VHL disease is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait and is characterized by a predisposition to a variety of neoplasms, particularly hemangioblastomas of the cerebellum and retina. Hundreds of bilateral renal cysts, often multiple, clear cell carcinomas develop in 40% to 60% of affected persons. Those with VHL syndrome inherit a germline mutation of the VHL gene on chromosome 3p. 

Manifestations of the von Hippel-Lindau Disease:

The most common lesions associated with VHL disease, are hemangioblastomas and typically occur in the cerebellum, spinal cord, or retina.

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) arises most commonly from the epithelial cells of the proximal convoluted tubule. It is more common in men and is found incidentally in many patients. The common subtypes are clear-cell, papillary, and chromophobe RCC. When confined to the kidney, surgery is the mainstay of treatment. Once the disease metastasized, tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) and mTOR (mammalian target of rapamycin) inhibitors can be used. 

Other options-

Option (C): Papillary RCC- It exhibits various degrees of papilla formation with fibrovascular cores. The histopathological section is shown below. 

 

Option (B): Chromophobe RCC-The cells of this type have clear granular cytoplasm with distinct cell membranes. The nuclei are surrounded by halos of the clear cytoplasm. The histopathological section is shown below.

 

Option (D): Collecting duct carcinoma (Bellini duct)- arises from collecting duct cells in the medulla. Several chromosomal losses and deletions have been described, but a distinct pattern has not been identified. Histologically these tumours are characterized by malignant cells forming glands enmeshed within a prominent fibrotic stroma, typically in a medullary location.

The given image shows a pathological examination of collecting duct carcinoma-

  • Associated with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease and tuberous sclerosis

Papillary type:

  • Caused by c-met mutation
  • Histology shows Psammoma bodies
  • Associated with hereditary papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Micropapillary variant is associated with long term dialysis

Chromophobe type:

  • Best prognosis

  • Caused by loss of multiple chromosomes (1, 2, 6, 10, 13) and extreme hypodiploidy

  • Originates from collecting tubules
  • Caused by deletion of 1q & monosomy of multiple chromosomes

Medullary type:

  • Poor prognosis
  • Originates from distal nephron
  • Associated with sickle cell anemia

questions.text: A newborn presents with respiratory distress, chest retractions, grunting, and cyanosis. The newborn was born via normal vaginal delivery and antenatal screening was not performed regularly.  Vital signs are remarkable for an elevated respiratory rate. The abdomen is scaphoid in shape and heart sounds are heard on the left side of the chest. Chest X-ray findings are shown in the image. Which of the following findings do you expect in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of congenital diaphragmatic hernia. Pulmonary hypertension is seen in a congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

Pulmonary hypertension is a poor prognostic indicator in a congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

Chest X-ray commonly shows bowel(gas-filled lumen) in the thorax and commonly the heart is shifted to the right(unlike in this case where hernia occurred on the right side hence pushing heart to the left)

Confounder - 
note that heart sounds are on the left side of the chest. However, most CDH occurs on the left side and displaces heart sounds to the right.

Management - 
External tracheal clips or endotracheal balloons laparoscopically placed to occlude the fetal trachea. Post-natal management mainly involves stabilization of the cardiorespiratory status. Immediate endotracheal intubation is critical.  If infants have a stable pulmonary status, CDH repair can be safely performed on the second to the fourth day of life.

Other options-

Option B - Pulmonary hyperplasia is not seen in CDH. Pulmonary hypoplasia is seen instead due to compression of the developing lung.

Option C - Esophageal atresia is seen as a part of 

  • VACTERL (vertebral anomalies, anal atresia, cardiac malformations, tracheoesophageal fistula, esophageal atresia, renal anomalies, and radial aplasia, and limb anomalies)

 

  • CHARGE (coloboma, heart defects, atresia of the choanae, retardation of mental and/or physical development, genital hypoplasia, and ear abnormalities

Option D - renal agenesis leads to Potter's syndrome with flat fascies. 

 

Related Pearl: Congenital diaphragmatic hernias (CDH)

It is due to the failure of the closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal in the developing fetus (Normally the pleuroperitoneal cavities separate by 8-10 weeks of gestation). Left-sided hernias are more common(80%).

The two well-recognized congenital sites where abdominal viscera can herniate into the chest are:

  • The foramen of Morgagni: a hernia in the anteromedial part of the diaphragm with a defect between the sternal and costal attachments. The most commonly involved viscus is the transverse colon.
  • The foramen of Bochdalek: through the dome of the diaphragm posterolaterally

CDH causes pulmonary hypoplasia (bilateral) by compressing the developing lung. These lungs have smaller bronchi, with less bronchial branching and less alveolar surface area than lungs in normal infants. Pulmonary hypertension may also develop due to increased thickness of arteriolar smooth muscle and also by multiple local and systemic vasoactive factors.

Clinical features:

  • respiratory distress at birth
  • grunting respiration
  • chest retractions
  • dyspnea
  • cyanosis
  • scaphoid abdomen
  • decreased breath sounds along with bowel sound over the chest with CDH
  • shifting of heart sounds to the right (for left-sided CDH)

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a 33-year-old male who is being assessed for peripheral vascular disease, a Fuchsig’s test is performed. Which of the following is true about this test?

choices.text: It tests for the tibial artery blood flow.
The patient sits cross-legged with the limb being assessed below the other limb.
Rhythmic oscillations of the leg indicate significant stenosis
Patient’s attention is diverted in the form of taking history

questions.solution:
The patient’s attention is diverted in the form of taking a history.

Fuchsig’s Test:
It is performed to detect popliteal pulsation. The patient is asked to sit cross-legged with the leg being examined resting above the other limb - such that the popliteal fossa of the leg being examined rests on the knee of the other limb as indicated in the image.

The crossed leg will show oscillatory movements of the foot which occur synchronously with the popliteal pulse and the oscillations will be absent if the popliteal artery is blocked.

questions.text: A 56-year-old patient with intractable ascites underwent a procedure as shown below. Identify the procedure.
questions.solution:
The image shows the transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt(TIPS) procedure with the viatorr device.

The main indication of TIPS is for variceal bleeds not responding to medical or endoscopic treatment, and intractable ascites.

The shunts are inserted under local anaesthetic, analgesia and sedation, using fluoroscopic guidance and ultrasonography. Via the internal jugular vein and superior venacava, a guidewire is inserted into a hepatic vein and through the hepatic parenchyma into a branch of the portal vein.

The main early complication of this technique is the perforation of the liver capsule and the main contraindication to TIPSS is portal vein occlusion.

    • Linton shunt (proximal lienorenal shunt with splenectomy)
    • ECK fistula (portocaval shunt)
    • Mitra shunt (splenorenal shunt)
  • Selective Shunt- only splenic blood is shunted
    • Warren shunt (distal lienorenal shunt)
    • Inokuchi shunt

questions.text: The operating surgeon inserted the following instrument after the exploration of  common bile duct. Identify this instrument.
questions.solution:
The image shows Kehr's T tube with the vertical and horizontal limbs.

Kehr's T tube is used after the exploration of common bile duct i.e. horizontal limb is placed in the common bile duct and vertical limb is brought out as drain. It allows bile to drain while the sphincter of Oddi is in spasm postoperatively. Once the sphincter relaxes, bile drains normally down the bile duct and into the duodenum.

Common bile duct T-tubes should remain in for 10 days. The 10-day period is required to minimize the risk of biliary peritonitis after removal. However, once the T-tube cholangiogram has shown that there is a free flow of bile into the duodenum and that there are no retained stones. some surgeons like to clamp the T-tube prior to removal.

Option B: Sengstaken-Blakemore tube is used to provide temporary hemostasis. It causes hemostasis by providing tamponade at the oesophagogastric junction.

Option C: Dobhoff tube is used for providing enteral nutrition.

Option D: Minnesota tube has 4 openings, 2 suction tubes, and 2 inflation tubes. Suction tubes allow aspiration of both gastric and oesophageal contents.

  • Stage Ib with perineural, lymphatic, vascular invasion and stage II, extended cholecystectomy should be performed

If the initial procedure was performed laparoscopically, the surgeon should examine the laparoscopic port sites. The finding of disease at the port sites is a sign of generalized peritoneal disease and carries a very poor prognosis. However, resection of port sites is no longer recommended.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented with cystic neck swelling as shown in the image. On examination, the swelling moves with deglutition and tongue protrusion. Which of the following malignancies may develop from this, if the swelling remains untreated?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient is a thyroglossal cyst. The most common cancer arising from a thyroglossal cyst is papillary carcinoma.

Though the most common complication of thyroglossal cyst is an infection, 1% of thyroglossal duct cysts are found to be malignant, with the most common type of cancer being papillary (85%). Medullary thyroid carcinomas are not found in thyroglossal duct cysts.

Management:

  • Sistrunk operation (en bloc cystectomy with excision of the central hyoid bone) is the procedure of choice for the surgical management of thyroglossal duct cysts. 
  • To minimize the recurrence of the cyst, the central portion of the hyoid is excised in addition to complete cyst excision including the entire tract.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the surgical OPD after she notices a lump while bathing. On examination, the lump is painless and located in the upper left quadrant of the left breast. Skin tethering and nipple retraction are present. There have been no similar complaints in her family. Mammography shows the following image. What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a 32-year-old woman with a painless lump showing skin tethering and puckering along with mammography showing egg-shell calcification is most likely to be traumatic fat necrosis.

Traumatic fat necrosis :

  • Traumatic fat necrosis may be acute or chronic and
  • It usually occurs in stout, middle-aged women.
  • Following a blow, or even indirect violence (e.g. contraction of the pectoralis major), a lump, often painless, appears.
  • A history of trauma is not diagnostic as this may merely have drawn the patient’s attention to a pre-existing lump
  • This may mimic a carcinoma, even displaying skin tethering and nipple retraction, and biopsy is required for diagnosis.
  • Fat necrosis is a frequently encountered cause of benign calcifications, particularly when there is a history of trauma or previous surgery. It presents as ‘egg shell’ calcifications within the wall of an oil cyst or as coarse dystrophic calcifications associated with areas of scarring.

Radiological findings in other diseases of the breast :

  • Popcorn calcification is seen in fibroadenoma.
  • Broken-needle type of calcification is seen in duct ectasia.

questions.text: A 31-year-old patient presented to the casualty with severe upper abdominal pain and recurrent retching without vomiting. A nasogastric tube insertion was tried but it was unsuccessful. His X-ray is shown below. Which of the following is most likely present in the above condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and X-ray showing a gas-filled viscus in the upper abdomen are suggestive of gastric volvulus. Borchardt's triad will most likely be present in a case of gastric volvulus.

Gastric volvulus is the rotation of the gastric fundus occurring on the longitudinal (organoaxial) or vertical (mesenteroaxial) axis of the stomach. This occurs due to the laxity in the peritoneal attachment of the stomach.

The Borchardt triad comprises:

  • Sudden-onset severe upper abdominal pain
  • Recurrent retching with minimal vomitus
  • Inability to pass a nasogastric (NG) tube

Organoaxial gastric volvulus is a torsion that occurs along the longitudinal axis of the stomach It is the most common type and often occurs acutely. It is associated with a diaphragmatic defect.

Mesenteroaxial gastric volvulus is a torsion that occurs along the vertical axis. It is partial (<180 degrees) and recurrent. It is not associated with a diaphragmatic defect.

 

Radiograph images shows a gas-filled viscus in the upper abdomen due to rotation of gastric fundus on the axis of the stomach. Gastric volvulus can be confirmed by a barium study. In barium study, the stomach may be inverted with greater curvature above the lesser curvature, or as the pylorus above the cardia. 

Emergency surgery is indicated for acute volvulus which includes decompression, reduction, and prevention of recurrence. The surgical intervention includes simple gastropexy with diaphragmatic hernia repair. 

Other options:

Option B- Dieulafoy’s triad is seen in acute appendicitis. It comprises of hypersensitiveness of skin, reflex muscular contraction, tenderness at Mc Burney’s point.

Option C- Quincke's triad is seen in hemobilia. It comprises upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage, abdominal pain, and obstructive jaundice.

Option D- Saint's triad comprises hiatus hernia, gallstones, and colonic diverticulosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man who serves in the military presents with a swelling in the natal cleft with occasional purulent discharge from it. He also complains of pain, and difficulty in sitting. On examination, a single point of discharge is seen. There is hair at the opening, but no feces are present. Per rectal examination has no significant findings.  What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation of a military personnel with swelling in the natal cleft associated with pain and discharge is suggestive of pilonidal sinus disease/jeep disease. 

Pilonidal sinus disease is commonly seen in the natal cleft, more in men, usually after puberty. Drivers and hairdressers are more commonly affected.

The pilonidal sinus opening is seen usually in the midline between the level of the sacrococcygeal joint and the tip of the coccyx. The other sites that they can be affected include the interdigital cleft and axilla.

Pathophysiology:

Buttock friction and shearing forces in this area allow broken hairs to enter the skin and create a subcutaneous, chronically infected midline track. An infected hair follicle can also form such a track. Secondary tracks can also form and are lined with granulation tissue and discharge. 

Clinical features:

  • Patients complain of intermittent pain, swelling, and discharge at the base of the spine.
  • A foreign-body-type reaction may then lead to the formation of an abscess.
  • Recurrence is common even after adequate excision of the tract.

Treatment

  • Conservative treatment: Strict hygiene and regular shaving of hair in the area.
  • Abscess:
    • Rest, baths, local antiseptic dressings, and broad-spectrum antibiotics.
    • If refractory to the above treatment- drainage with thorough curettage of granulation tissue and hair.
  • Surgical techniques: Bascom’s, Karydaki's procedures are for chronic pilonidal disease.

Other options :

Options A - Hidradenitis suppurativa refers to follicular occlusion, folliculitis and secondary infection with skin flora. This leads to chronic suppurative, painful, skin abscesses, sinus tracts, and scarring. It usually occurs in skin containing apocrine glands, like the axillae and groins. It runs in the caudad direction while pilonidal sinus runs in a cephalad direction. They are usually found in the perineum while pilonidal sinus is found in the natal cleft. 

The following image shows a hidradenitis suppurativa lesion with multiple boils and points of discharge.

Option C - Anal fistula is an abnormal communication, that runs outwards from the anorectal lumen to an external opening on the skin of the perineum or buttocks. It presents with bloody discharge and in some cases feces in the sinus tract while a pilonidal abscess/sinus does not. The internal opening is usually palpated as a point of induration in rectal examination.

Options D - Postanal dermoid is a cystic condition that usually remains asymptomatic until adult life. Hair is not found in the sinus tract. The cyst is easily palpable on rectal examination. Pressure over the sacrococcygeal region with a finger in the rectum may cause a flow of sebaceous material. A bottle-necked cyst is visualized in the front of the coccyx upon injection of contrast media followed by radiography. Given the background of serving in the military, postanal dermoid is less likely to be the answer to this question.

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic female patient presents to you with complaints of greenish nipple discharge for the past few months. Examination reveals the presence of discharge from multiple ducts with para-areolar lump and advised for mammography. Which of the following mammography findings, you would expect in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of duct ectasia and mammogram of a patient with duct ectasia shows typical Broken-needle type of calcification.  This is due to the calcification of debris within dilated ducts.

Duct ectasia is the dilatation of breast ducts. It is the most common cause of nipple discharge in nonlactating women. This condition is associated with smoking and diabetes.

The initial stage of this disease consists of dilatation of one or more lactiferous ducts. These ducts get filled with stagnant brown or green colored secretions. In the later stages, the accumulation of fluid in the lactiferous ducts leads to infection and inflammation, causing periductal mastitis. The infections are most often mixed infections of aerobic and anaerobic flora of the skin.

Initial episodes can be managed with antibiotics. Recurrent episodes of the disease are best managed by Hadfield operation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for damage control surgery?
questions.solution:
Serum lactate >5 mmol/L is an indication for damage control surgery.

Indications for damage control surgery:

Anatomical:

  • Inability to achieve hemostasis
  • Complex abdominal injury, e.g. liver and pancreas
  • Combined vascular, solid, and hollow organ injury, e.g. aortic or caval injury
  • Inaccessible major venous injury, e.g. retrohepatic vena cava
  • Demand for non-operative control of other injuries e.g. fractured pelvis
  • Anticipated need for a time-consuming procedure

Damage control surgery is minimal intervention done to stabilize the patient and do the definite surgery later. It centers on coordinating staged operative interventions with periods of aggressive resuscitation to salvage trauma patients sustaining major injuries.

Phase I (Initial Exploration) -

This phase consists of an initial operative exploration to attain rapid control of active hemorrhage and contamination.

Phase II (Secondary Resuscitation) -

This phase focuses on secondary resuscitation to correct hypothermia, coagulopathy and acidosis.

Phase III (Definitive Operation) -

It consists of planned re-exploration and definitive repair of injuries. This phase typically occurs 48 to 72 hours following initial and after successful secondary resuscitation.

Patients with IgA deficiency are at risk of severe anaphylactic reactions associated with plasma transfusion. But, usually, allergic reactions during blood transfusions are related to plasma proteins found in transfused components. It occurs following a transfusion of a few milliliters of blood components. questions.text:
The barium swallow images of different conditions of the esophagus are given below. Which of the following images represents the condition characterized by the features given below?
  1. Normal integrated relaxation pressure in manometry.
  2. Premature spastic contractions.
  3. Distal contractile integral (DCI) >450 mmHg.
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given features is diffuse esophageal spasm (DES)/ Distal esophageal spasm. Image B showing a rosary bead or corkscrew appearance of the esophagus on a barium swallow represents the condition.

DES is a hypermotility disorder of the esophagus which manifests as dysphagia and chest pain that may radiate to the jaw, arms, and upper back. It is more common in the distal two-thirds of the oesophageal body. Muscular hypertrophy and degeneration of the branches of the vagus nerve in the esophagus are seen in this condition. Oesophageal contractions are repetitive, simultaneous, and of high amplitude. 

The diagnosis of DES is made by radiographic and manometric studies. Manometric findings are:

  • Normal integrated relaxation pressure in manometry.
  • Premature spastic contractions.
  • Distal contractile integral (DCI) >450 mmHg.

On barium swallow, a rosary bead or corkscrew appearance is seen. It indicates tertiary contractions and advanced disease.

Treatment is with long-acting nitrates, calcium channel-blocking agents, sedatives, and anticholinergics. Bougie dilation of the esophagus relieves dysphagia in many patients. Intrasphincteric injection of botulinum toxin has been tried. Surgery is indicated for patients who fail to respond to medical or endoscopic therapy.

 
Other options:

Image A: Achalasia cardia is characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis. It affects men more than women. A barium swallow shows the presence of a characteristic bird's beak appearance. It is shown below.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presenting with abdominal pain and intractable peptic ulcers is suspected to have Zollinger–Ellison syndrome.  His gastric pH is 1.5 and his fasting serum gastrin level was found to be 600pg/mL (normal <100pg/ml). What is the next best step to be done in this case?

choices.text: Level of basal acid output is measured.

questions.solution:
The given fasting serum gastrin level of 600pg/mL in a patient suspected to have Zollinger–Ellison syndrome is considered equivocal. The next best step to be done in this case is to do a secretin stimulation test. 

To confirm the diagnosis of ZES,

  • Gastric pH should be <2 and
  • Serum gastrin should be >10 times normal (normal <100pg/ml)

Provocative tests can be done like the secretin stimulation test when the diagnosis is in doubt. 

Serum gastrin samples are measured before and after IV secretin administration. An increase of more than 200 pg/mL of serum gastrin above basal levels is suggestive of gastrinoma.

Conditions that can rise serum gastrin levels are:

  • Use of proton pump inhibitors.
  • H. pylori infection.
  • Renal failure.

Zollinger Ellison Syndrome (ZES)/Gastrinoma is a neuroendocrinal tumor characterized by hypersecretion of gastrin resulting in gastrointestinal tract ulcers. It occurs more commonly in a sporadic pattern but can be associated with MEN-1 (multiple endocrine neoplasia-1) syndromes in the familial pattern.

Treatment of ZES

High-dose Proton Pump Inhibitor followed by surgery.

Surgeries that can be done are:

  • Distal Pancreatectomy – if a lesion in the body or tail of the pancreas
  • Enucleation – if a lesion in the head of the pancreas
  • Full-thickness excision – if lesion in duodenum
  • MEN associated – surgery done only if size>2.5cm  

 For metastatic tumors:

24 hr pH monitoring is used in the diagnosis of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). 

Related Pearl: Passaro’s Triangle

Around 90% of gastrinomas are found in this triangle.

Its boundaries are as follows:

  • Junction of the cystic duct and common bile duct
  • Junction of the 2nd and 3rd parts of the duodenum
  • Junction of the body and neck of the pancreas

Most common symptom: Abdominal pain.

Gastrin hypersecretion stimulates gastric acid secretion, leading to peptic ulcers that occur at atypical sites like the duodenum and jejunum and are refractory and multiple.

Diarrhea is due to

  • Acid-induced injury to the small intestine mucosa
  • Inability of the intestinal tract to absorb large volumes of fluids secreted by the stomach
  • Inactivation of pancreatic lipase by low pH
  • Precipitation of bile salts.

The unique characteristic of acid-induced diarrhea is that it is controlled by nasogastric aspiration of gastric secretions.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic tests in Zollinger Ellison Syndrome

  • Gastric pH <2.5 and
  • Serum gastrin >1000pg/ml (normal <100pg/ml)

Provocative tests can be done like the secretin stimulation test when the diagnosis is in doubt. An increase in serum gastrin >200pg/ml following an IV bolus of secretin (2U/kg) is diagnostic.

Other tests:

  • BAO >15mEq/h (or >5mEq/h if they have had a procedure for peptic ulcer)
  • BAO: MAO ratio is increased (>0.6)

(BAO=Basal acid output; MAO=Maximal acid output)

For localization

  • Initial investigation - CT or MRI
  • Best investigation - Endoscopic ultrasound
  • If the tumor is not localized - Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy.

questions.text: What is the best position for the patient to be in while inserting the given tube for enteral feeds?
questions.solution:
The given image is Ryle's tube. The best position for this patient during the insertion of Ryle's tube is sitting with neck flexion.

Nasogastric tube/ Ryle's tube is used to provide enteral feeds. It is also used to diagnose the patency of the esophagus in conditions like tracheoesophageal fistula. If enteral feeds are continued for more than a week then a fine bore tube is used. 

It is inserted by standing perpendicular to the patient and the distance is calculated using the NEX method.

NEX method:
  • The tip of the nose to ear to xiphisternum.
  • The tube length should be estimated before insertion.
  • Place the exit port of the tube at the tip of the nose. Extend tube to the earlobe, and then to xiphisternum.

Confirmation of the correct position is done by auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air and X-ray chest. 

Approximate length: 120-125 cm

Markings indicating traversing of the tube through various parts of the stomach:

1) 40 cm - Traversed cardia of the stomach

2) 50 cm - Traversed body of stomach

3) 60 cm - Traversed pylorus

4) 70 cm - Tube has traversed Duodenum

Indications for NG tube:

  • Aspiration of gastric fluid
  • Gastric decompression in cases of intestinal obstruction and paralytic ileus.
  • Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is characterized by hypersecretion of gastrin resulting in acid-induced diarrhea that is controlled by nasogastric aspiration of gastric secretions 
  • Feeding
  • Administration of medication
  • Bowel irrigation

Contraindications for NG tube:

  • Absolute:
    • Severe midface trauma
    • Recent nasal surgery
    • Basilar skull fractures
  • Relative:
    • Coagulation abnormality
    • Caustic ingestion
    • Esophageal trauma/ obstruction
    • Esophageal varices
    • Recent banding of esophageal varices
    • Anastomoses in the stomach and esophagus

questions.text: The procedure shown in the image below is being performed on a 35-year-old male patient, who presented with complaints of dysphagia, regurgitation, and chest pain. His barium swallow showed a bird's beak appearance near the gastroesophageal junction. What is the procedure performed on this patient known as?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of achalasia cardia, and the procedure shown above is called peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM). 

Achalasia is a primary esophageal motility disorder caused due to the degeneration of neurons in the myenteric plexus of the esophagus. It is characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), thereby causing a functional obstruction at the gastroesophageal junction.  

The patients present with a triad of dysphagia, regurgitation, and weight loss. The dysphagia initially begins with liquid foods and then progresses to solid foods, halitosis is present due to the accumulation of food. Patients may develop pneumonia, lung abscess, etc. at a later stage.

The initial diagnosis is made by barium swallow or endoscopy, which shows the presence of dilated esophagus due to the constriction of the lower esophageal sphincter (bird beak appearance). The gold standard test to confirm achalasia cardia is esophageal manometry. The findings are impaired lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation and absent peristalsis with elevated LES pressure. 

The image below shows the bird beak appearance of the esophagus on the barium swallow.

 Management is as follows:

  • Heller's myotomy
  • Partial fundoplication
  • Peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM) is mainly done for type 1 and 2. For type 3, it is done if there is recurrence after surgery. 

    In this procedure, the mucosa of the esophagus is divided around the mid to the distal third, and a submucosal tunnel is created; through this tunnel, the muscular layer of the distal esophagus, lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and cardia are visualized and divided.

    The major downside of POEM is that an effective anti-reflux valve cannot be created, exposing the patient to a 40–50% risk of post-procedural gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). 

 Other options:

Option A: NOTES - Natural orifice transluminal endoscopic surgery - It helps access the peritoneal cavity or the abdominal cavity through the gastrointestinal tract, without incising the anterior abdominal wall. It is in the experimental stage and is proposed to replace laparoscopic appendicectomy or cholecystectomy. 

Option B: SILS - Single incision laparoscopic surgery - It is also known as 'scarless’ surgery. It has recently been applied in recent times for gallbladder removal or complex biliopancreatic procedures to minimize the invasiveness of the surgery. 

Option D: ROSE -  Restorative obesity surgery endoscopy helps restore the stomach pouch and size of the outlet in patients who have undergone gastric bypass to help them regain back the weight.

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the condition shown below?

choices.text: Bilateral in more than 50% of the cases
Affects males more often than females

questions.solution:
The given intravenous urography (IVU) image depicts cobra head/adder head deformity which is a classic sign of ureterocele. It is associated with dysplastic renal tissue.

Ureterocele:

A ureterocele is the cystic enlargement of the intramural ureter. It is thought to be caused due to ureteric orifice atresia. It is observed more in females than males in a 4:1 preponderance and is bilateral in about 10% of the cases. They are similar to ectopic ureters wherein the upper pole of the kidney is drained. This condition is typically associated with dysplastic and non-functional renal tissue.

Clinical presentation:

  • Children with ureterocele usually present with infection.
  • Adults present with renal stones.

Diagnosis:

  • IVU shows a classical cobra head sign but is relatively infrequently performed these days.
  • Cystoscopy shows a bulging, translucent swelling involving the ureteric orifice where there is urinary stasis. It is emptied by ureteric peristalsis.

Treatment:

  • Surgical excision with re-implantation of the ureter is the treatment of choice for simple ureterocele.
  • Renal stones associated with ureterocele are removed using an endoscopic incision
  • An advanced disease that causes hydronephrosis or pyonephrosis is an indication for nephrectomy.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man with a known case of sickle cell disease presented with sustained painful penile erection for the last 5 hours. Blood gas analysis from the penis shows hypoxia, hypercapnia, and acidosis. Aspiration of the sludge of blood and intracavernosal injection of phenylephrine failed to produce a response. What should be the next best line of management?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette in this patient is suggestive of ischemic priapism secondary to sickle cell disease and the next best line of management among the given options is to perform Quackel's shunt. It is a proximal shunt between corpora cavernosa and spongiosum. 

Priapism refers to a persistent erection lasting >4 hours, not related to sexual stimulation. There are two types of priapism:

  • Ischemic -more common
  • Non-ischemic

Ischaemic priapism occurs due to venous congestion, and consequent thrombosis. On examination, the penis is tender. Blood gas analysis of penile blood shows hypoxia, hypercapnia, and acidosis. Risk factors for priapism are sickle cell disease or trait, malignancy, medications, cocaine abuse, and total parenteral nutrition.

Detumescence should be ensured in 6-12 hours to avoid progressive, irreversible damage to the corpus cavernosal tissue with subsequent fibrosis and erectile dysfunction. Initial management can be done with oral agents like pseudoephedrine or baclofen.

  • First-line treatment- Aspiration of the sludged blood in the corpora cavernosa
    • By insertion of a large 18-gauge needle into the lateral aspect of one corporal body 
  • Intracavernosal injection of phenylephrine (an alpha-adrenoceptor agonist) is the next line of therapy.
  • Surgical shunts
    • Distal shunts like Winter shunt (in the emergency room), Al-Ghorab shunt (operative shunt)
    • Proximal shunts like Quackel shunt (proximal cavernosum-spongiosum), Grayhack (corporal-saphenous vein)

For those with sickle cell disease, hydration and oxygen administration should be performed first. 

Non-ischemic priapism usually occurs after blunt perineal trauma. A fistula develops between the central penile artery and the sinusoidal space, leading to a persistent, painless erection. Blood gas analysis shows characteristics of arterial blood. Treatment is not an emergency and is done by selective arterial embolization. (option D)

Other options:

Options A and B- Glansectomy and penectomy are generally performed for penile carcinoma.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the OPD with a history of a lump in the left breast. On clinical examination, the size of the lump in the left breast is 9×10 cm with the following appearance and no axillary lymphadenopathy. The histopathology of the biopsy from the lump shows increased stromal cellularity and typical leaflike architecture. What is your likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image is suggestive of Phyllodes tumor or cystosarcoma phyllodes of the breast.

Phyllodes tumor, also known as cystosarcoma phyllodes, presents as a large tumor with an unevenly bosselated surface. This tumor does not infiltrate the skin though the overlying skin becomes thin and tense due to swelling. Nipple retraction is not seen in this condition.

The histopathology of the biopsy of the lump shows increased stromal cellularity, overgrowth, and typical leaflike architecture which is suggestive of a phyllodes tumor. Axillary dissection is not done if malignant transformation occurs because the lymphatic spread is rare.

Phyllodes tumors usually occur in women over the age of 40 years but can appear in younger women. Phyllodes tumor is mostly benign even though it is also called cystosarcoma phyllodes or as serocystic disease of Brodie. They are usually mobile over the chest wall despite their large size. Histologically, there is a wide variation with some of the low malignant potential and others having a higher mitotic index.

Treatment of phyllodes tumor:

  • Benign type- Enucleation or wide local excision
  • Massive tumors, recurrent tumors, and malignant type- Mastectomy

The histopathology of the biopsy of the lump shows increased stromal cellularity, overgrowth, and typical leaflike architecture which is suggestive of a phyllodes tumor.

 

Other options:

Giant fibroadenomas are usually seen in the early reproductive years. These are benign solid encapsulated tumors. It is a slow-growing tumor and presents as a painless lump in the breast.

Inflammatory breast cancer is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The pathologic hallmark of inflammatory cancer is the presence of tumor cells within dermal lymphatics. Axillary nodal metastases are common, and there is a significant risk for distant metastases.

Patients with inflammatory carcinoma usually have a history revealing the rapid onset of the disease with progression over weeks to 3 months.

The hallmark of inflammatory breast cancer is diffuse tumor involvement of the dermal lymphatic channels within the breast and overlying skin, often without an underlying tumor mass. Inflammatory breast cancer manifests clinically as erythema, edema, and warmth of the breast as a result of lymphatic obstruction.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman was incidentally found to have a liver mass while undergoing ultrasound for renal calculi. CECT showed the following image. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with contrast-enhanced CT showing hypervascular lesion with a central non-enhancing scar points towards focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH).

Focal nodular hyperplasia is the second most common benign tumour in the liver and is mostly seen in women. This condition is characterised by focal overgrowth of functional liver tissue and the supporting fibrous stroma.

Patients are mostly asymptomatic and FNH is often an incidental finding. If patients are symptomatic, they usually complain of abdominal pain.

On histological examination, cords of hepatocytes are seen with atypical biliary epithelium scattered throughout. A central stellate scar containing a large artery branching out in a spoke-wheel pattern is also seen.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman who is a chronic smoker had recurrent retroareolar infections and abscesses. The condition she is suffering from is________.
questions.solution:
Zuska’s disease, also called recurrent periductal mastitis, is a condition of recurrent retro areolar infections and abscesses. Smoking has been implicated as a risk factor for this condition. Managed symptomatically by antibiotics coupled with incision and drainage as necessary.

Other options: 

Option A: Tietze’s Syndrome is a benign inflammation of one or more costal cartilages.

Option B: Mondor’s disease is thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast and anterior chest wall.

Option D: Paget's disease of the nipple is a superficial manifestation of underlying breast carcinoma. It presents as an eczema-like condition of the nipple
